Award.AwardTitle: Scholarships for Service for FSU MS CC and CNSA Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to expand the existing CyberCorps(R): Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at Florida State University (FSU) to new MS Computer Criminology degree program. Most professionals who enter the cybersecurity field have only training in technical aspects with the common educational background being Computer Science (CS). While such skills are crucial, there is also a need to have a broader understanding of the threat model for cyber applications particularly when the adversary can be an insider. Criminology studies the extent, causes and nature of criminal behavior in the individual, society or nation-state. Understanding the motivation for criminal behavior leads to better methods for the prevention of cybercrime and, when complemented with the appropriate CS technical skills will provide assurance in a much more realistic threat model. Thus, CS and Criminology provide complementary knowledge skills. FSU has created a new MS Computer Criminology degree program to meet these needs. Another key aspect of this project is to increase female and minority participation in cybersecurity attracting students that would have normally majored in criminology or related majors.

The proposed project has an important mission of preparing cybersecurity professionals for positions in agencies of the Federal, state, local and tribal government. Using knowledge and skills obtained in the program, the graduates are well prepared to meet challenges of protecting the information and infrastructure resources of our Nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The SFS program for Cyber Criminology (CC) and Computer Network & System Administration (CNSA) at FSU has funded 36 scholars during the 2013-2018 grant period. Seven scholars in the last cohort were transferred to NSF grant 1565215 to complete their graduate studies, and two scholars left the program (but are fully paid back). The other scholars (27) graduated with an average cumulative GPA: 3.715, and are currently employed at government agencies.

The SFS CC/CNSA education program is a training program for students with a background in Cyber Criminology or Network and Systems Administration, to obtain analytical and computational skills so as to be able to play a leading role in securing cyberspace. Students graduate from this program with an MS in Cyber Criminology (MS CC) or an MS in Computer Network & System Administration (MS CNSA).

  • FSU recruits qualified students from all over Florida, offering them courses in Information Assurance and Cyber Defense both at the undergraduate and graduate levels, while providing an environment that encourages learning and research in cybersecurity. By targeting cyber criminology, the recruiting pool is expanded to allow for a much broader diversity with over 55% female students and over 33% underrepresented.
  • The CC/CNSA program has grown significantly over time. One reason for this is the introduction of several hands-on education/training security courses that employ CTF competitions/challenges, and that address real world cyber attack scenarios, and motivate students to develop analytical skills. These courses attract students from a broad pool of disciplines into the CC/CNSA program. Several students end up taking additional Computer Science courses and graduate with an MS in Computer Science. However, were it not for this option, these students would not follow a cyber defense career.
  • We have developed hands-on courses for: Practical Cyber Operations,  Offensive Computer Security, Offensive Network Security and Reverse Engineering,  that integrate security analysis tools, learning experience and lab materials based on CTF challenges. These courses are very popular with undergraduate students and promote the SFS program at FSU.
  • SFS scholars from the CC/CNSA program with their breadth of knowledge based on cyber criminology and their experience in cyber defense operations are ready to adapt dynamically to ongoing cyber threats to serve our nation.

Last Modified: 03/30/2019
Modified by: Mike Burmester
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The SFS program for Cyber Criminology (CC) and Computer Network & System Administration (CNSA) at FSU has funded 36 scholars during the 2013-2018 grant period. Seven scholars in the last cohort were transferred to NSF grant 1565215 to complete their graduate studies, and two scholars left the program (but are fully paid back). The other scholars (27) graduated with an average cumulative GPA: 3.715, and are currently employed at government agencies. The SFS CC/CNSA education program is a training program for students with a background in Cyber Criminology or Network and Systems Administration, to obtain analytical and computational skills so as to be able to play a leading role in securing cyberspace. Students graduate from this program with an MS in Cyber Criminology (MS CC) or an MS in Computer Network & System Administration (MS CNSA). FSU recruits qualified students from all over Florida, offering them courses in Information Assurance and Cyber Defense both at the undergraduate and graduate levels, while providing an environment that encourages learning and research in cybersecurity. By targeting cyber criminology, the recruiting pool is expanded to allow for a much broader diversity with over 55% female students and over 33% underrepresented. The CC/CNSA program has grown significantly over time. One reason for this is the introduction of several hands-on education/training security courses that employ CTF competitions/challenges, and that address real world cyber attack scenarios, and motivate students to develop analytical skills. These courses attract students from a broad pool of disciplines into the CC/CNSA program. Several students end up taking additional Computer Science courses and graduate with an MS in Computer Science. However, were it not for this option, these students would not follow a cyber defense career. We have developed hands-on courses for: Practical Cyber Operations, Offensive Computer Security, Offensive Network Security and Reverse Engineering, that integrate security analysis tools, learning experience and lab materials based on CTF challenges. These courses are very popular with undergraduate students and promote the SFS program at FSU. SFS scholars from the CC/CNSA program with their breadth of knowledge based on cyber criminology and their experience in cyber defense operations are ready to adapt dynamically to ongoing cyber threats to serve our nation.
